docs.lead_paragraph: A large clinical trial of older male physicians followed for more than a decade found that those taking a daily multivitamin experienced 8 percent fewer cancers than the subjects taking dummy pills.

headline.seo: Daily Multivitamin May Reduce Cancer Risk, Clinical Trial Finds
headline.main: Multivitamin Use Linked to Lowered Cancer Risk
headline.print_headline: Multivitamin Use Linked To Lowered Cancer Risk

docs.abstract: Journal of American Medical Association publishes results from a large clinical trial of nearly 15,000 older male doctors followed for more than a decade, finding that those taking a daily multivitamin experienced 8 percent fewer cancers than subjects taking dummy pills.
docs.snippet: A large clinical trial of older male physicians followed for more than a decade found that those taking a daily multivitamin experienced 8 percent fewer cancers than the subjects taking dummy pills.

keywords.value: Journal of the American Medical Assn
keywords.name: organizations

docs.lead_paragraph: Health authorities and breast-feeding advocates are urging hospitals to stop handing out samples of formula, saying they can undermine the resolve to breast-feed.

headline.seo: Hospitals Ditch Formula Samples to Promote Breast-Feeding
headline.main: Hospitals Ditch Formula Samples to Promote Breast-Feeding

docs.abstract: Health authorities and breast-feeding advocates are leading a nationwide effort to ban hospitals from sending young mothers home with samples of infant formula; health experts say the practice can sway women away from breast-feeding.
docs.snippet: Health authorities and breast-feeding advocates are urging hospitals to stop handing out samples of formula, saying they can undermine the resolve to breast-feed.

docs.lead_paragraph: The drug agency said Monday that products from a Massachusetts company linked to a meningitis outbreak may have also caused other types of infections.

headline.seo: Wider Meningitis Risk From Tainted Drugs Feared
headline.main: F.D.A. Warns of Further Risk From Tainted Drugs
headline.print_headline: New Infections May Be Linked To Drug Maker

docs.abstract: Food and Drug Administration officials warn more people may be at risk from contaminated drugs made by New England Compounding Center, Massachusetts company linked to growing meningitis outbreak that has killed 15 patients and infected almost 200 others in 15 states; report the company's products may have also caused other types of infections in patients who have had eye operations or open-heart surgery.
docs.snippet: The drug agency said Monday that products from a Massachusetts company linked to a meningitis outbreak may have also caused other types of infections.

byline.original: By DENISE GRADY and SABRINA TAVERNISE

docs.lead_paragraph: A steroid drug tainted with a fungus has been recalled in a meningitis outbreak, but more cases are expected, even as experts examine why only a fraction of the people exposed have fallen ill.

headline.seo: Tracing Crucial Components of Meningitis Outbreak
headline.main: Steroid Shot Near Spine Gives Illness an Opening
headline.print_headline: Steroid Shot Near Spine Gives Illness An Opening

docs.abstract: Doctors are working to understand why some patients treated with a fungus-tainted steroid drug that caused a national meningitis outbreak have become ill while others have not; one factor may be whether the needle used to administer the drug, which is commonly injected near the spine, pierced the spinal membrane, allowing the fungus into the spinal fluid.
docs.snippet: A steroid drug tainted with a fungus has been recalled in a meningitis outbreak, but more cases are expected, even as experts examine why only a fraction of the people exposed have fallen ill.

keywords.value: St Thomas Outpatient Neurosurgery Center (Nashville, Tenn)
keywords.name: organizations

docs.lead_paragraph: As recent disparate conclusions on organic produce show, the way data is handled in a meta-analysis — a statistical compilation of earlier work by others — can make a difference in the findings.

headline.seo: Stanford Organic Food Study and Vagaries of Meta-Analyses
headline.main: Parsing of Data Led to Mixed Messages on Organic Food’s Value
headline.print_headline: Parsing of Data Led to Mixed Messages on Organic Food’s Value

docs.abstract: Debate has erupted in response to two studies, conducted at Newcastle University in England and Sanford University, comparing organic fruits and vegetables to conventionally grown produce; Newcastle researchers found that organic produce was more nutritious, whereas the Stanford study debunked its nutritional advantage;
docs.snippet: As recent disparate conclusions on organic produce show, the way data is handled in a meta-analysis — a statistical compilation of earlier work by others — can make a difference in the findings.
